1️⃣

What is a quantum computation?

There is not a single answer to that question. The standard ways of modelling quantum computations with qubits include the quantum circuit model, measurement-based quantum computing and adiabatic quantum computing. Note that there are many others, and that qubits are far from being the only option for manipulating quantum information.

1.1 Qubit quantum computation

In a classical computer, the most basic unit of information is a bit, which can take two values: 000﻿ and 111﻿. In a quantum computer, the laws of quantum physics allow phenomena like superposition and entanglement. When discussing information processing in a quantum world, the most basic unit is therefore a quantum bit, usually called qubit, a two-level quantum system with a ground state ∣0⟩|0\rangle∣0⟩﻿ and an excited state ∣1⟩|1\rangle∣1⟩﻿. Unlike a classical bit, which only has two possible states, a quantum bit has infinitely many states: all superpositions of ∣0⟩|0\rangle∣0⟩﻿ and ∣1⟩|1\rangle∣1⟩﻿,

where α\alphaα﻿ and β\betaβ﻿ are complex numbers satisfying ∣α∣2+∣β∣2=1|\alpha|^2+|\beta|^2=1∣α∣2+∣β∣2=1﻿. A measurement of this qubit state in the so-called computational basis ∣0⟩,∣1⟩|0\rangle,|1\rangle∣0⟩,∣1⟩﻿ gives the result 0 with probability ∣α∣2|\alpha|^2∣α∣2﻿ and the result 1 with probability ∣β∣2|\beta|^2∣β∣2﻿.

A useful tool for visualizing a qubit state is the Bloch sphere. A state of the qubit is represented as a point on the surface of the sphere, which has radius 111﻿. The two states of a classical bit correspond to the north and south poles on the sphere. The two states on opposite ends of the xxx﻿ axis are often denoted

the so-called diagonal basis.

If there are NNN﻿ qubits in a system, the total state of that system can be a superposition of 2N2^N2N﻿ different states: ∣000...00⟩|000...00\rangle∣000...00⟩﻿, ∣100...00⟩|100...00\rangle∣100...00⟩﻿, ∣010...00⟩|010...00\rangle∣010...00⟩﻿, ..., ∣111...10⟩|111...10\rangle∣111...10⟩﻿, ∣111...11⟩|111...11\rangle∣111...11⟩﻿ (note the abbreviated notation of the tensor product). NNN﻿ classical bits can be in one of these 2N2^N2N﻿ states, but not in a superposition of several of them. To store all the information about a general NNN﻿-qubit state, one needs to keep track of the 2N2^N2N﻿ amplitudes in the superposition. This means that at least 2N2^N2N﻿ classical bits may be required to represent the quantum system. This provides intuition for why it may be hard for classical computers to simulate some quantum systems and gives a first hint that quantum computers can be more powerful than classical ones.

There are many physical implementations of qubits, e.g., superconducting qubits, trapped ions, natural atoms, photons, etc. For now, we assume that we have access to qubits without caring too much about how they are made.

1.1.1 The quantum circuit model

Introduction

Loosely speaking, a computation requires a system that can represent data, a way to perform manipulation of that data, and a method for reading out the result of the computation. In the circuit model of quantum computation we use:

  • Qubits to represent the data.
  • State preparation to initialize the qubits in the input state we need to begin the computation.
  • Quantum gates on the qubits to manipulate the data.
  • Measurements on the qubits to read out the final result.

For brevity, we assume that it is possible to initialize our quantum computer in some simple state, e.g., ∣000...00⟩|000...00\rangle∣000...00⟩﻿, and that we can read out the state of the qubits at the end of a computation in the computational basis ∣0⟩,∣1⟩|0\rangle,|1\rangle∣0⟩,∣1⟩﻿.

Single-qubit gates

Operations on a single qubit moves its state from ∣ψ⟩=α∣0⟩+β∣1⟩|\psi\rangle=\alpha|0\rangle+\beta|1\rangle∣ψ⟩=α∣0⟩+β∣1⟩﻿ to ∣ψ′⟩=α′∣0⟩+β′∣1⟩|\psi'\rangle=\alpha'|0\rangle+\beta'|1\rangle∣ψ′⟩=α′∣0⟩+β′∣1⟩﻿ while preserving the norm ∣α∣2+∣β∣2=1=∣α′∣2+∣β′∣2|\alpha|^2+|\beta|^2=1=|\alpha'|^2+|\beta'|^2∣α∣2+∣β∣2=1=∣α′∣2+∣β′∣2﻿. Such operations (gates) can be described by 2×22\times22×2﻿ unitary matrices.

This gate transforms a qubit state from the computational basis ∣0⟩,∣1⟩|0\rangle,|1\rangle∣0⟩,∣1⟩﻿ to the diagonal basis ∣+⟩,∣−⟩|+\rangle,|-\rangle∣+⟩,∣−⟩﻿. The Hadamard gate is often used to create superposition states at the beginning of a quantum algorithm.

Multi-qubit gates

To realize useful quantum algorithms, we also need to be able to make two or more qubits interact through multi-qubit gates. One way to achieve this is to let the state of one qubit (the control qubit) control whether a certain single-qubit gate is applied to another qubit (the target qubit). One such gate is the controlled-NOT (CNOT\text{CNOT}CNOT﻿) gate:

where I2I_2I2​﻿ denotes the 2×22\times22×2﻿ identity matrix. Note that the two-qubit Hilbert space is spanned by the basis vectors ∣00⟩,∣01⟩,∣10⟩,∣11⟩|00\rangle,|01\rangle,|10\rangle,|11\rangle∣00⟩,∣01⟩,∣10⟩,∣11⟩﻿, in that order. This is the tensor product of the two single-qubit Hilbert spaces. The action of the CNOT\text{CNOT}CNOT﻿ gate is thus to do nothing if the first qubit is in state ∣0⟩|0\rangle∣0⟩﻿ and to apply NOT (an XXX﻿ gate) to the second qubit if the first qubit is in state ∣1⟩|1\rangle∣1⟩﻿.

The controlled-Z (CZ\text{CZ}CZ﻿) gate can be defined in the same manner:

There are also two-qubit gates that are not controlled operations. For example, the SWAP\text{SWAP}SWAP﻿ gate

swaps the states of two qubits.

It is also possible to define gates involving more than two qubits. For three-qubit gates, the most well-known ones are the Toffoli and Fredkin gates.

The Toffoli\text{Toffoli}Toffoli﻿ gate is a controlled-controlled-NOT (CCNOT\text{CCNOT}CCNOT﻿), i.e., the state of the third qubit is flipped if and only if both the first two qubits are in state ∣1⟩|1\rangle∣1⟩﻿:

The Fredkin\text{Fredkin}Fredkin﻿ gate is a controlled-SWAP (CSWAP\text{CSWAP}CSWAP﻿) gate, swapping the states of the second and third qubits if and only if the state of the first qubit is ∣1⟩|1\rangle∣1⟩﻿:

Most practical implementations of quantum computing have limited connectivity between qubits, only allowing for pairwise interactions between nearest-neighbour qubits. This can prohibit direct implementations of multi-qubit gates with three or more qubits, but it turns out that any multi-qubit gate can be decomposed into a number of single- and two-qubit gates.

Measurements

In the quantum circuit model, the measurement is typically assumed to be in the computational basis. It assigns the observed quantum state to a single value, according to the Born rule: a measurement of a quantum state ∣ψ⟩=α∣0⟩+β∣1⟩|\psi\rangle=\alpha|0\rangle+\beta|1\rangle∣ψ⟩=α∣0⟩+β∣1⟩﻿ in the computational basis gives the outcome 000﻿ with probability ∣α∣2|\alpha|^2∣α∣2﻿ and the outcome 111﻿ with probability ∣β∣2|\beta|^2∣β∣2﻿.

The application of a quantum gate can be conditioned on the classical outcome of a measurement.

Universal quantum circuits

Are all the gates we specified above enough to carry out any quantum computation that we would like? Could we do any quantum computation using just a small subset of the gates above? These are questions about universality.

For classical computers, a set of gates is called universal if, by applying enough gates from this set in a sequence, it is possible to express any Boolean function on any number of bits. The classical TOFFOLI gate turns out to be universal all on its own, but there are other sets of gates that are not universal. For example, the set {AND,OR} is not universal, because these gates cannot express non-monotone Boolean functions; changing an input bit from 0 to 1 in a circuit with these gates will never result in an output bit changing from 1 to 0. For quantum computers, a gate set is called universal if the gates therein can be used to approximate any unitary transformation on any number of qubits up to any desired precision. To understand what makes a gate set universal for quantum computing, let us first see how a gate set can fail to be universal.

  • Inability to create superposition states: some gates, e.g., XXX﻿ and CNOT\text{CNOT}CNOT﻿, map all states in the computational basis into other states in the computational basis (e.g, CNOT∣11⟩=∣10⟩\text{CNOT}|11\rangle=|10\rangleCNOT∣11⟩=∣10⟩﻿). These gates can maintain superpositions, but they cannot create new ones.
  • Inability to create entanglement: the Hadamard gate can create a superposition (e.g., H∣0⟩=∣+⟩H|0\rangle=|+\rangleH∣0⟩=∣+⟩﻿), but it only acts on a single qubit, so it cannot create entanglement between two or more qubits. Clearly, no single-qubit gate can. Since an unentangled state of NNN﻿ qubits can be written as (α1∣0⟩+β1∣1⟩)⊗⋯⊗(αN∣0⟩+βN∣1⟩)(\alpha_1|0\rangle+\beta_1|1\rangle)\otimes\dots\otimes(\alpha_N|0\rangle+\beta_N|1\rangle)(α1​∣0⟩+β1​∣1⟩)⊗⋯⊗(αN​∣0⟩+βN​∣1⟩)﻿, it can be specified using only 2N2N2N﻿ amplitudes, which a classical computer would be able to simulate efficiently.

Let us try a slightly larger set of quantum gates:

Equivalently, this is the group generated by the gate set {HHH﻿,SSS﻿,CNOT\text{CNOT}CNOT﻿} [Gottesman1997].

If we take our gate set to be {HHH﻿,SSS﻿,CNOT\text{CNOT}CNOT﻿}, we circumvent the objections above. However, it turns out that this still is not enough to achieve universal quantum computation:

Quantum circuits with gates in the Clifford group are also called stabilizer circuits (a formal definition while be given in Part II of the course, where a proof of the Gottesman–Knill theorem and quantum error correction are discussed). If one starts in the computational basis, the single-qubit states that can be reached using these circuits are the ±1\pm1±1﻿ points on the xxx﻿, yyy﻿, and zzz﻿ axes of the Bloch sphere. This restriction of the state space turns out to make the circuit classically simulable, even though the state space includes states with both superposition and entanglement.

What is then a universal gate set? Actually, replacing either the SSS﻿ or HHH﻿ gate in the last gate set considered above, {HHH﻿,SSS﻿,CNOT\text{CNOT}CNOT﻿}, with almost any other single-qubit gate makes the set universal [Shi2002]. One common universal gate set is {HHH﻿,CNOT\text{CNOT}CNOT﻿,TTT﻿}. Almost any two-qubit gate on its own is also universal. Interestingly, {H,ToffoliH,\text{Toffoli}H,Toffoli﻿} is a universal gate set for quantum computations [Aharonov2003], while TOFFOLI is universal for classical computations.

Such sets can approximate any unitary transformation on any number of qubits to any desired precision ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿. However, it is a different question whether that approximation is fast and efficient. For example, if the number of gates needed would scale exponentially in 1/ϵ1/\epsilon1/ϵ﻿, there would probably not be any practical use for such a universal gate set. Luckily, there is a theorem telling us that the scaling for any universal gate set is much more benign:

See [Dawson2006] for a proof. What this theorem essentially says is that if we have a gate set that can approximate any single-qubit rotation, then we only need relatively few gates from that set to do the approximation, so we can do the approximation fast. For certain gate sets, the number of gates can be brought down from O(log⁡4(1/ϵ))O(\log^4(1/\epsilon))O(log4(1/ϵ))﻿ to O(log⁡(1/ϵ))O(\log(1/\epsilon))O(log(1/ϵ))﻿ [Harrow2002]. By adding some two-qubit gates to make the gate set universal, the total number of gates needed to approximate a quantum circuit of mmm﻿ constant-qubit gates is at most O(mlog⁡4(m/ϵ))O(m\log^4(m/\epsilon))O(mlog4(m/ϵ))﻿.

Together with the observations above, this gives us confidence that quantum computing has potential:

  • We know how to find a universal gate set to approximate any unitary transformation.
  • We know that we can implement that approximation efficiently.
  • We know that we can implement any unitary operation on NNN﻿ qubits in a realistic experimental architecture that allows for a few single- and two-qubit gates.

Does that mean that we can run quantum algorithms that are faster than classical algorithms for some problems? This will be discussed in the next chapters, see Section 2.

1.1.2 Measurement-based quantum computing

Introduction

In the previous section, we have encountered the circuit model for performing quantum computations. From the point of view of computer science this is the most natural model, as it is a direct analogue of the classical circuit model on which the architecture of our (classical) computers is based. However, quantum information allows for other, much more exotic, models of computation. Many of these models were originally proposed with the idea that they might be more powerful than the circuit model, although ultimately they were proved equivalent. This includes adiabatic quantum computing which we cover in the next section, and measurement-based quantum computing (MBQC) that we will now study.

In the circuit model of quantum computation, we prepare an initial state, apply a sequence of quantum gates to this state, and finally do some measurement on the output state to obtain the result of the computation. While this seems a natural order of operations, which agrees with our intuition for how a classical computation is performed, it is possible to mix up the order somewhat.

In MBQC, we first prepare a certain fixed entangled state of qubits, known as a graph state, where a subset of these qubits represent the input state. This entangled state is the resource for our computation. In the rest of the computation, we never need to apply any multi-qubit operations. All we do is apply single-qubit rotations and single-qubit measurements in some sequence, where later rotations are conditioned on earlier measurement results. The output state will be encoded in a subset of the qubits (different from the subset that encoded the input), and a final measurement can be performed on this output state to read out the result of the computation.

Because of the presence of measurements in earlier steps of the computation, MBQC differs from the circuit model in one important aspect: it is not reversible. In the circuit model, we apply a large unitary transformation (decomposed into a sequence of gates) that takes us from the input state to the output state. Before any measurement is done on the output state, this unitary transformation could be reversed to bring us back to the input state. However, since measurements are done before we reach the output state in MBQC, that computation cannot be reversed. For this reason, MBQC has been introduced as one-way quantum computation [Raussendorf2001]. More details can be found in the follow-up paper [Raussendorf2003]. The first experimental demonstration of all basic components of MBQC was performed in 2005 [Walther2005].

Let’s give an overview of how this model works.

Single-qubit MBQC

The previous exercise gave us a toy example of the concept of gate teleportation: by entangling our input state with a specific ancillary state, performing a measurement and applying a correction based on the outcome, we ended up applying a unitary gate to our input state. MBQC can be thought of as a generalisation of this process based on ∣+⟩|+\rangle∣+⟩﻿ states and CZ\text{CZ}CZ﻿ gates.

Let’s do another simple example. Suppose we have a qubit initialized in the state ∣ψ⟩=α∣0⟩+β∣1⟩|\psi\rangle=\alpha|0\rangle+\beta|1\rangle∣ψ⟩=α∣0⟩+β∣1⟩﻿. Suppose a second qubit is created in the state ∣+⟩|+\rangle∣+⟩﻿ and a CZ\text{CZ}CZ﻿ operation is performed, controlling on the first qubit to perform a phase flip on the second. Then, the joint state of the system is α∣0⟩∣+⟩+β∣1⟩∣−⟩α|0⟩|+⟩+β|1⟩|−⟩α∣0⟩∣+⟩+β∣1⟩∣−⟩﻿. Suppose now that we measure the first qubit in the Hadamard basis. What happens to the second qubit? Let’s rewrite:

In the first case, ∣ϕ⟩=H∣ψ⟩|\phi⟩ = H|ψ⟩∣ϕ⟩=H∣ψ⟩﻿, and in the second ∣ϕ⟩=XH∣ψ⟩|\phi⟩ = XH|ψ⟩∣ϕ⟩=XH∣ψ⟩﻿. More succinctly put, ∣ϕ⟩=XmH∣ψ⟩|\phi⟩=X^mH|ψ⟩ ∣ϕ⟩=XmH∣ψ⟩﻿, where m∈{0,1}m\in\{0,1\}m∈{0,1}﻿ denotes the outcome of the measurement (m=0m = 0m=0﻿ in case of “+++﻿” and m=1m = 1m=1﻿ in case of “−−−﻿”). Note that these are the rotations obtained in the previous section by exponentiating Pauli operations, up to an irrelevant global phase.

Together, the rotations Rz(φ)R_z (φ )Rz​(φ)﻿ (in the XXX﻿-YYY﻿ plane) and Rx(φ)R_x (φ )Rx​(φ)﻿ (in the ZZZ﻿-YYY﻿ plane) generate a universal set of single-qubit gates, as any rotation on the Bloch sphere can be implemented as Rz(φ3)Rx(φ2)Rz(φ1)R_z(φ_3)R_x(φ_2)R_z(φ_1)Rz​(φ3​)Rx​(φ2​)Rz​(φ1​)﻿ for an appropriate choice of φ1φ_1φ1​﻿, φ2φ_2φ2​﻿ and φ3φ_3φ3​﻿ (the RzR_zRz​﻿ rotations can bring the initial and final states in the ZZZ﻿-YYY﻿ plane). The following exercise asks you to generalize our example of the Hadamard gate to any single-qubit rotation that is decomposed in this way.

This exercise almost lets us apply an arbitrary rotation Rz(φ3)Rx(φ2)Rz(φ1)R_z(φ_3)R_x(φ_2)R_z(φ_1)Rz​(φ3​)Rx​(φ2​)Rz​(φ1​)﻿, except there are corrections (the XXX﻿, ZZZ﻿ and Hadamard gates to the left) and extra (−1)mi(−1)^{m_i}(−1)mi​﻿ phases in the rotation angles. But these can be dealt with easily. For the phases, note that we perform the measurements sequentially, and the phase flip that got applied to a certain angle only depends on the outcome of the measurement performed right before. For the case of the calculation performed in the exercise, if we really had wanted to end up with Rx(φ2)R_x(φ_2)Rx​(φ2​)﻿, after having obtained outcome m1m_1m1​﻿ we would have updated our choice of angle to φ2′=(−1)m1φ2φ_2'=(−1)^{m_1}φ_2φ2′​=(−1)m1​φ2​﻿. As for the XXX﻿, ZZZ﻿ and HHH﻿ corrections at the end of the computation, we can handle those at the time of final measurement: they correspond to corrections that will need to be applied once we measure the final qubit.

This shows how any sequence of single-qubit rotations can be applied to a qubit. You would start with a line of mmm﻿ qubits, each initialized in the ∣+⟩|+⟩∣+⟩﻿ state. Then, apply CZ\text{CZ}CZ﻿ operations on all pairs of neighboring qubits, from left to right. This corresponds to preparing a 1×m1 × m1×m﻿-dimensional brickwork state, our universal resource for single-qubit computation. Suppose for simplicity the initial qubit is meant to be initialized in the ∣+⟩|+⟩∣+⟩﻿ state (if it is not you can modify the circuit so that the first gate applied prepares the correct qubit). Any rotation can be applied by decomposing it in the form Rz(φ3)Rx(φ2)Rz(φ1)R_z(φ_3)R_x(φ_2)R_z(φ_1)Rz​(φ3​)Rx​(φ2​)Rz​(φ1​)﻿ and making the correct sequence of measurements on three qubits, keeping track of successive measurement outcomes to update the angles and the XXX﻿, ZZZ﻿ and HHH﻿ corrections (note that we do not need to remember all measurement outcomes, but only their combined effect in terms of a power of XXX﻿ and a power of ZZZ﻿, using XaZb=(−1)abZbXaX^aZ^b=(-1)^{ab}Z^bX^aXaZb=(−1)abZbXa﻿).

Multi-qubit MBQC

What if we have a multi-qubit computation? Recall that a single entangling gate is enough to provide universality together with all single-qubit operations. Since the CZ\text{CZ}CZ﻿ gate comes for free in MBQC, we can implement any computation by combining the technique from the previous section with additional gates. However, in that case, the underlying graph state will be highly dependent on the computation to be performed. As it turns out, there exist simple graph states that are universal resources for MBQC, meaning that one can embed any quantum computation within the same graph structure. Then, it is sufficient to tune the measurement angles

One such graph state is the brickwork state: we use multiple lines of qubits, one per qubit of the computation; the lines are connected by vertical CZ\text{CZ}CZ﻿ operations once every three qubits in a slightly shifted manner.

This graph allows to implement single-qubit unitary operations as before, by setting the first three angles appropriately and all remaining angles to 000﻿. Moreover, a two-qubit CNOT\text{CNOT}CNOT﻿ gate can be applied using similar ideas as we described, but performing measurements on the two lines associated with both qubits on which the gate acts. We leave the details as an exercise below. Finally, the concatenation of brickwork states allows to implement gates in sequence.

The brickwork state is not the only universal resource state for MBQC. For instance, it has been shown that a square lattice graph state (a cluster state) is a universal resource for quantum computation. Despite this fact, depending on the specific kind of computation, other graphs than a square lattice could be more suitable for implementing the computation. Note that not all graph states are equally useful for quantum computing, and there are powerful tools to determine whether a given graph state can give rise to deterministic MBQC [Browne2007].

It is clear that MBQC requires much more qubits than the circuit model to perform the same computation. However, these qubits can be measured earlier, necessitating lower coherence time than in the circuit picture. Moreover, it can be shown (for instance through the brickwork state construction) that any quantum circuit can be implemented in MBQC with at most a polynomial overhead in terms of number of qubits. Reciprocally, through the deferred measurement principle, any MBQC can be turned into a quantum circuit efficiently, by pushing all the measurements to the end of the computation. While fundamentally different in nature, those two models of quantum computations thus are equivalent from a computational point of view!

1.1.3 Adiabatic quantum computing

Introduction

We close this section with a discussion of a third model of quantum computation: adiabatic quantum computing (AQC). The basic idea of AQC is to perform a quantum computation by varying the interaction Hamiltonian of a physical system. At t=0t=0t=0﻿, the system is in the ground state of an initial Hamiltonian H(0)H(0)H(0)﻿. At t=Tt=Tt=T﻿, the Hamiltonian has been evolved to a final Hamiltonian H(1)H(1)H(1)﻿. Provided it stays in a ground state, the state of the system ends up in a ground state of H(1)H(1)H(1)﻿. If the initial Hamiltonian H(0)H(0)H(0)﻿ is simple enough, it is easy to initialize the system in this ground state. Then, the Hamiltonian H(1)H(1)H(1)﻿ is chosen such that its ground space encodes the solution of a certain computational problem. This means that the adiabatic evolution will provide us with a way to probe this solution. Note that AQC is closely related to quantum annealing, which also encodes the solution to a problem in the ground state of some final Hamiltonian.

At this point, there are two issues to deal with:

  • How do we encode a computational problem in the ground space of a Hamiltonian?
  • How do we make sure that the state of a system stays in the ground space of its Hamiltonian during its evolution?

Encoding computational problems in the ground state of a Hamiltonian

The answer to the first question is based on the definition of a ground state.

A direct consequence of this definition is that a ground state ∣ψ⟩|\psi\rangle∣ψ⟩﻿ has minimal energy ⟨ψ∣H∣ψ⟩=min⁡∣ϕ⟩⟨ϕ∣H∣ϕ⟩\langle\psi|H|\psi\rangle=\min_{|\phi\rangle}\langle\phi|H|\phi\rangle⟨ψ∣H∣ψ⟩=min∣ϕ⟩​⟨ϕ∣H∣ϕ⟩﻿. Indeed, any state ∣ϕ⟩|\phi\rangle∣ϕ⟩﻿ can be decomposed in an orthonormal eigenbasis {∣ψk⟩}k\{|\psi_k\rangle\}_k{∣ψk​⟩}k​﻿ of HHH﻿ as

Writing λk\lambda_kλk​﻿ the eigenvalue associated to the eigenstate ∣ψk⟩|\psi_k\rangle∣ψk​⟩﻿ and λ\lambdaλ﻿ the smallest eigenvalue of HHH﻿, we have

where δkl\delta_{kl}δkl​﻿ is the Kronecker symbol.

In other words, by preparing a ground state of a Hamiltonian HHH﻿ and measuring its energy, we can approximate the solution of the optimisation problem min⁡∣ϕ⟩⟨ϕ∣H∣ϕ⟩\min_{|\phi\rangle}\langle\phi|H|\phi\ranglemin∣ϕ⟩​⟨ϕ∣H∣ϕ⟩﻿. How is this useful in practice? It turns out we can encode other important optimization problems using this Hamiltonian energy minimization problem. Let us consider a specific example: the Max-Cut problem.

The Max-Cut problem is a common combinatorial optimization problem in graph theory that has important applications in statistical physics and circuit design. We do not know any efficient algorithm that can solve this problem perfectly.

In graph theory, a graph is represented by a pair of sets G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E)﻿, where the elements in the set VVV﻿ are the vertices of the graph and each element in the set EEE﻿ is a pair of vertices, representing an edge connecting these two vertices.

A cut on a graph refers to a partition of the graph's vertex set VVV﻿ into two disjoint sets V0V_0V0​﻿ and V1V_1V1​﻿. Each cut corresponds to a set of edges, in which the two vertices of each edge belong to different sets. We can define the size of this cut as the size of this set of edges, that is, the number of edges being cut. The Max-Cut problem is to find a cut that maximizes the number of edges being cut.

Assuming that the input graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E)﻿ has n=∣V∣n=|V|n=∣V∣﻿ vertices and m=∣E∣m=|E|m=∣E∣﻿ edges, we can describe the Max-Cut problem as a combinatorial optimization problem with nnn﻿ bits and mmm﻿ clauses as follows:

  • Each bit corresponds to a vertex vvv﻿ in the graph GGG﻿ and its value zvz_vzv​﻿ is 000﻿ or 111﻿, corresponding to the vertex belonging to the set V0V_0V0​﻿ or V1V_1V1​﻿, respectively. Each string z=(zv)v∈V\bm z=(z_v)_{v\in V}z=(zv​)v∈V​﻿ of nnn﻿ bits then corresponds to a distinct cut.
  • Each clause corresponds to an edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v)﻿ in the graph GGG﻿ and its value C(u,v)(zu,zv)C_{(u,v)}(z_u,z_v)C(u,v)​(zu​,zv​)﻿ is 111﻿ or 000﻿, depending on whether or not the two vertices connected by its corresponding edge take different values, namely zu≠zvz_u\neq z_vzu​=zv​﻿, which means the edge is cut, or zu=zvz_u=z_vzu​=zv​﻿, respectively. In particular, we can set C(u,v)(zu,zv)=zu+zv−2zuzvC_{(u,v)}(z_u,z_v)=z_u+z_v-2z_uz_vC(u,v)​(zu​,zv​)=zu​+zv​−2zu​zv​﻿.

The objective function of the entire combinatorial optimization problem is then given by

and the Max-Cut problem is to maximize this function given the description of the graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E)﻿.

Let us encode this problem in the ground state of a quantum Hamiltonian. We use nnn﻿ qubits, where each qubit corresponds to a vertex in the graph GGG﻿. A qubit being in a quantum state ∣0⟩|0\rangle∣0⟩﻿ or ∣1⟩|1\rangle∣1⟩﻿ indicates that its corresponding vertex belongs to the set V0V_0V0​﻿ or V1V_1V1​﻿, respectively. These states are the two eigenstates of Pauli ZZZ﻿ gate, and their eigenvalues are respectively 111﻿ and −1-1−1﻿. Because the function f(x):x→(1−x)/2f(x):x\rightarrow(1-x)/2f(x):x→(1−x)/2﻿ maps 111﻿ to 000﻿ and −1-1−1﻿ to 111﻿, for all v∈Vv\in Vv∈V﻿ we can replace zvz_vzv​﻿ in the equation above by the operator (I−Zv)/2(I-Z_v)/2(I−Zv​)/2﻿, where III﻿ is the identity matrix and ZvZ_vZv​﻿ the Pauli ZZZ﻿ gate acting on the qubit corresponding to the vertex vvv﻿ and identity on all the other qubits, to get the Hamiltonian corresponding to the objective function of the original problem:

By construction, the maximum energy of that Hamiltonian is the solution to the Max-Cut problem. Hence, if we define the Hamiltonian HG:=∑(u,v)∈EZuZvH_G:=\sum_{(u,v)\in E}Z_uZ_vHG​:=∑(u,v)∈E​Zu​Zv​﻿, finding its ground state energy λ\lambdaλ﻿ is equivalent to solving the Max-Cut problem for the graph GGG﻿, since its solution will be given by ∣E∣/2−λ/2|E|/2-\lambda/2∣E∣/2−λ/2﻿.

In practice, we only have access to energy measurements, which will yield approximations of the true ground state energy, assuming our system is in a ground state of our target Hamiltonian. This leads us to the second question: how do we make sure that the state of a system stays in the ground space of its Hamiltonian during its evolution?

The quantum adiabatic theorem

The answer to the second question is the content of the quantum adiabatic theorem: informally, this theorem implies that a quantum system which begins in the non-degenerate ground state of a time-dependent Hamiltonian will remain close to the instantaneous ground state provided the Hamiltonian changes sufficiently slowly (adiabatically). What is sufficiently slowly? We will see that the timescale for adiabaticity is intimately connected to the energy gap between the ground and first excited states.

When the Hamiltonian of a quantum system does not depend on time, the dynamics of that system are fairly straightforward. Given a time-independent Hamiltonian HHH﻿, the solution of the Schrödinger equation

with the initial quantum state ∣ψ(0)⟩|ψ(0)⟩∣ψ(0)⟩﻿, is given by ∣ψ(t)⟩=exp⁡(−iHt)∣ψ(0)⟩|ψ(t)⟩ = \exp(−iHt)|ψ(0)⟩∣ψ(t)⟩=exp(−iHt)∣ψ(0)⟩﻿. So any eigenstate ∣Ψ⟩|\Psi⟩∣Ψ⟩﻿ of the Hamiltonian, with H∣Ψ⟩=E∣Ψ⟩H|\Psi⟩ = E|\Psi⟩H∣Ψ⟩=E∣Ψ⟩﻿, simply acquires a phase exp⁡(−iEt)\exp(−iEt)exp(−iEt)﻿. In particular, there are no transitions between eigenstates: a system that starts in the ground state ends in the ground state.

If the Hamiltonian varies in time, the evolution it generates can be considerably more complicated.

Let H(s)H(s)H(s)﻿, 0≤s≤10 ≤ s ≤ 10≤s≤1﻿, be a Hamiltonian dependent on a parameter sss﻿. We refer to HHH﻿ as a time-dependent Hamiltonian. We think of H(0)H(0)H(0)﻿ as the initial Hamiltonian and of H(1)H(1)H(1)﻿ as the final Hamiltonian. For a time-dependent Hamiltonian HHH﻿, we use the notation ∥H∥∥H∥∥H∥﻿ to denote max⁡s∈[0,1]∥H(s)∥\max_{s∈[0,1]} ∥H(s)∥maxs∈[0,1]​∥H(s)∥﻿ where ∥⋅∥∥ \cdot ∥∥⋅∥﻿ is the usual operator norm. We use a similar notation to denote the maximum norm (or absolute value) of other time-dependent expressions. A prime symbol ′'′﻿ indicates a derivative.

Let Ψ(s)Ψ(s)Ψ(s)﻿ be an eigenstate of H(s)H(s)H(s)﻿ with eigenvalue λ(s)λ(s)λ(s)﻿ (in most applications, Ψ(s)Ψ(s)Ψ(s)﻿ is chosen to be the ground state of H(s)H(s)H(s)﻿). When we say that we apply the adiabatic evolution given by HHH﻿ and ΨΨΨ﻿ for time TTT﻿ we mean that we initialize a system in the state Ψ(0)Ψ(0)Ψ(0)﻿ and then apply the continuously varying Hamiltonian H(t/T)H (t/T)H(t/T)﻿ for times t∈[0,T]t ∈ [0, T ]t∈[0,T]﻿. If TTT﻿ is large enough, we expect the final state of the system to be close to Ψ(1)Ψ(1)Ψ(1)﻿. The quantum adiabatic theorem is a formal description of this phenomenon. There are many quantitative versions of this theorem [Albash2018]; in what follows, we focus on the following version:

The quantum adiabatic theorem identifies a crucial parameter: the spectral gap (or energy gap, or simply gap) of the Hamiltonian. In particular, it implies that as long as HHH﻿ has a 1/poly1/\mathrm{poly}1/poly﻿ spectral gap around γγγ﻿, we can reach a state that is at most 1/poly1/\mathrm{poly}1/poly﻿ away from Ψ(1)Ψ(1)Ψ(1)﻿ in polynomial time. Note that it is possible to improve the dependence on Δ\DeltaΔ﻿ to Δ3\Delta^3Δ3﻿ or even Δ2\Delta^2Δ2﻿ for specific families of Hamiltonians [Albash2018]. Note also that this theorem is valid for any eigenstate (not necessarily the ground state). In the remainder of the section we will only consider the ground state and the gap between the ground space and the first excited space, i.e., between the smallest eigenvalue of the Hamiltonian and its second smallest eigenvalue.

1.2 Beyond qubits
1.2.1 Qudits and qumodes

Qubits are the natural information-theoretic building blocks when using 222﻿-level quantum systems. However, many physical systems are typically not 222﻿-level systems, and their higher-order degrees of freedom may also be manipulated. Examples include: spin higher than 1/21/21/2﻿, orbital angular momentum, particle number, but also continuous degrees of freedom such as position or momentum.

Qudits

The natural information-theoretic description of a 333﻿-level quantum system is a qutrit, and more generally a qudit for ddd﻿-level quantum systems. A qudit state is a normalized complex vector in a Hilbert space of dimension ddd﻿:

Of course, it is always possible to embed a qudit Hilbert space in the Hilbert space of multiple qubits. However, operations that may be naturally implemented at the qudit level may correspond to operations that are more challenging to implement at the qubit level.

Much like a qubit state can be represented by a single point at the surface of the Bloch sphere, a qudit state may be represented by d−1d-1d−1﻿ points at the surface of a sphere, which is known as the Majorana stellar representation [Serrano-Ensástigua2019]. The Pauli matrices may also be defined for qudits by their action on the qudit computational basis {∣0⟩,…,∣d−1⟩}\{|0\rangle,\dots,|d-1\rangle\}{∣0⟩,…,∣d−1⟩}﻿: for all k∈{0,…,d−1}k\in\{0,\dots,d-1\}k∈{0,…,d−1}﻿,

where ⊕\oplus⊕﻿ is the addition modulo ddd﻿ and ωd=e2iπ/d\omega_d=e^{2i\pi/d}ωd​=e2iπ/d﻿ is a dthd^{th}dth﻿ root of unity. Note that contrary to the qubit case, the qudit Pauli operators are d×dd\times dd×d﻿ unitary matrices that are not hermitian. Instead, we have Xd=Zd=IX^d=Z^d=IXd=Zd=I﻿, where III﻿ is the d×dd\times dd×d﻿ identity matrix.

As it turns out, the Gottesman—Knill theorem also holds for qudit Clifford computations in odd dimensions [Kocia2017]. More generally, there is a large litterature on qudit-based quantum information theory which we refer the interested reader to [Wang2020].

Qumodes

Up to now, we have been focussing on finite-dimensional Hilbert spaces. What if the local dimension of the Hilbert is infinite? It turns out this gives a meaningful way of dealing with continuous quantum degrees of freedom, such as the position or momentum of a quantum system, but also with infinite discrete quantum properties, such as the number of particles. Nonetheless, this formalism is often referred to as continuous-variable quantum information theory.

In that context, the natural information-theoretic building block is the qumode, or simply mode. The quantum state of a single mode is a normalized complex vector in a separable Hilbert space of infinite dimension. The separability property is a topological feature of the space which ensures that two states that are different can be physically told apart. In practice, this property is equivalent to the existence of a countable orthonormal basis {∣n⟩}n∈N\{|n\rangle\}_{n\in\mathbb N}{∣n⟩}n∈N​﻿ of the Hilbert space. The quantum state of a single mode can then be written in that basis as

This countable basis is often referred to as the Fock basis, the photon-number basis, or simply the number basis. Depending on the way information is encoded, it may or may not be the computational basis. The Fock state ∣0⟩|0\rangle∣0⟩﻿ is referred to as the vacuum state and the Fock state ∣1⟩|1\rangle∣1⟩﻿ as the single-photon state.

Once again, it is always possible to truncate a qumode Hilbert space and embed it in a finite-dimensional Hilbert space of multiple qubits. However, this induces truncation errors and, similar to the qudit case, operations that may be naturally implemented at the qumode level may correspond to operations that are more challenging to implement at the qubit level.

1.2.2 Phase-space representations

We refer the reader to [Cahill1969] for an in-depth introduction to the material presented in this section. In particular, we restrict to single-mode quantum states and operators on an infinite-dimensional Hilbert space.

Quantum phase space

The expectation values of the position and momentum operators lie in the so-called quantum phase space, which is the quantum analogue of classical phase space. Continuous-variable quantum states and operators can be alternatively described by their phase-space representation. In particular, this formulation identifies a quantum state with a normalised distribution over phase space, which in the case of a single-mode is the complex plane C\mathbb CC﻿.

This allows for a simple and experimentally relevant classification of quantum states: those with a Gaussian phase-space distribution are called Gaussian states and the others non-Gaussian states. By extension, unitary operations mapping Gaussian pure states to Gaussian pure states are also called Gaussian. As it turns out, this class of Gaussian unitary operations corresponds exactly to the group of Gaussian unitary operations from the previous definition. Interestingly, these Gaussian operations and states are the ones implementable with linear optics and quadratic non-linearities, and are hence relatively easy to construct experimentally.

Hereafter, we label points of the single-mode phase space as α∈C\alpha\in\mathbb Cα∈C﻿, where the real part corresponds to expectation values of the position operator and the imaginary part to expectation values momentum operator. We adopt the convention α=12(q+ip),α=\frac1{\sqrt2}(q+ip),α=2​1​(q+ip),﻿ with d2απ=dℜ(α)dℑ(α)π=dqdp2π\frac{d^2α}\pi=\frac{d\Re(α)d\Im(α)}\pi=\frac{dqdp}{2\pi}πd2α​=πdℜ(α)dℑ(α)​=2πdqdp​﻿.

There exists a continuum of equivalent phase space distributions representing the same operator in phase space. This continuum of representations is parametrized by a real parameter s≤1s≤1s≤1﻿. For all s≤1s≤1s≤1﻿ and all ∣α⟩∈C|\alpha\rangle\in\mathbb C∣α⟩∈C﻿, let us define the operator

The same definition holds for density operators, in which case the representation is real-valued and corresponds to the expectation value of the operator TTT﻿. The phase-space representations are normalised as ∫α∈CWρ(α;s)d2απ=Tr(ρ)\int_{\alpha\in\mathbb C}W_ρ(α;s)\frac{d^2\alpha}π =\mathrm{Tr}(ρ)∫α∈C​Wρ​(α;s)πd2α​=Tr(ρ)﻿, for all s≤1s ≤ 1s≤1﻿ and for any density operator ρρρ﻿.

The Wigner function

The Wigner function is a nonsingular distribution for all states and is referred to as a quasiprobability distribution, as it is a normalised distribution which can take negative values. This contrasts with classical phase-space probability distributions. This type of non-classicality can be interpreted through the lens of non-Gaussianity for pure states:

The Wigner function can be expressed as WA(α)=2πTr(D(α)ΠD†(α)A)W_A(α)=\frac2π\mathrm{Tr}(D(α)ΠD^\dag(α)A)WA​(α)=π2​Tr(D(α)ΠD†(α)A)﻿ for all α∈Cα ∈\mathbb Cα∈C﻿ and for any operator AAA﻿, where Π=(−1)a†a=∑n=0+∞(−1)n∣n⟩⟨n∣Π=(−1)^{a^\dag a} = \sum_{n=0}^{+\infty}(−1)^n|n\rangle\langle n|Π=(−1)a†a=∑n=0+∞​(−1)n∣n⟩⟨n∣﻿ is the parity operator. The Glauber—Sudarshan PPP﻿ function

The Glauber–Sudarshan PPP﻿ function is the most singular phase space representation. For quantum states, it is actually always a singular distribution. The PPP﻿ function provides a convenient diagonal expansion of a state in coherent state basis as

Husimi QQQ﻿ function

The Husimi Q function is a smoother version of the Wigner function and the Glauber—Sudarshan PPP﻿ function. It is given by

for all α∈C\alpha\in\mathbb Cα∈C﻿ and any operator AAA﻿, where ∣α⟩|α\rangle∣α⟩﻿ is the coherent state of amplitude α∈Cα ∈ \mathbb Cα∈C﻿. The Husimi QQQ﻿ function of a state thus is always nonnegative and normalised. However, it does not represent probabilities of mutually exclusive states since the overlap between two coherent states is always nonzero.

Hudson’s theorem may be formulated as follows for the Husimi function [Lütkenhaus1995]: a pure quantum state is non-Gaussian if and only if its Husimi function has zeros. In other words, a pure quantum state is non-Gaussian if and only if it is orthogonal to at least one coherent state.

Gaussian operations

Gaussian states and processes have been defined in the previous section, the former as the states having a Gaussian phase space representation and the latter as the processes mapping Gaussian states to Gaussian states. Ubiquitous in quantum physics, they are well understood theoretically and routinely implemented experimentally. We review Gaussian processes and states in the following, restricting to pure states, unitary operations and projectors.

The displacement operator D(α)D(\alpha)D(α)﻿ of amplitude α∈Cα ∈\mathbb Cα∈C﻿ which has been introduced in the previous section is a Gaussian operation. It may be conceived as acting on a state by displacing its phase-space representation.

Another Gaussian operation is the squeezing operator, defined as

with ξ∈C\xi\in\mathbb Cξ∈C﻿. It may be conceived as acting on a state by squeezing its phase-space representation. This geometrical intuition holds in particular for the Wigner function. Any single-mode Gaussian unitary operation may be written as a squeezing and a displacement operator. The ordering is only a convention, since the displacement and squeezing operators satisfy the braiding relation

for all α∈Cα ∈\mathbb Cα∈C﻿ and all ξ=riθ∈C\xi=r^{i\theta} ∈\mathbb Cξ=riθ∈C﻿.

Another common single-mode Gaussian operation is the phase-space rotation, or phase-shift operator, defined as

with θ∈R\theta\in\mathbb Rθ∈R﻿. It may be conceived as acting on a state by rotating its phase-space representation.

In the multimode case, the two-mode mixing operator is a passive linear transformation defined as

Finally, Gaussian projectors are identified with projections onto Gaussian pure states, which we cover in what follows.

Gaussian states

General single-mode Gaussian pure states are obtained from the vacuum with a Gaussian unitary operation. They are the squeezed coherent states (or alternatively the displaced squeezed vacuum states):

for all α,ξ∈Cα,ξ ∈\mathbb Cα,ξ∈C﻿. Setting ξ=0ξ = 0ξ=0﻿ we obtain a coherent state of amplitude α∈Cα ∈ \mathbb Cα∈C﻿, while setting α=0α = 0α=0﻿ we obtain a squeezed vacuum state with squeezing parameter ξ∈Cξ ∈ \mathbb Cξ∈C﻿.

The phase-space representation of a coherent state is a Gaussian function displaced in phase space, while the phase-space representation of a squeezed vacuum state is a Gaussian centered at 000﻿, squeezed in a direction depending on the phase of the squeezing parameter. The strength of the squeezing depends on the modulus of the squeezing parameter. In particular, position and momentum eigenstates can be conceived formally as infinitely squeezed vacuum states, displaced by a finite amplitude.

As it turns out, the Gottesman—Knill theorem also holds for qumode Gaussian computations [Bartlett2001]. By Hudson’s theorem, this implies that Wigner negativity provides the ‘magic’ for continuous-variable quantum computations, i.e., it is a necessary non-Gaussian resource for quantum computational advantage. This statement has been further extended to mixed states [Mari2012].
